metadata.case_name: Instalment Supply Pvt. Ltd. v. State of Gujarat

facts.text: Petitioner is a limited company with registered office in New Delhi carrying on business of financing purchase of motor vehicles through hire-purchase agreements.

Under hire-purchase agreement, hirer pays initial deposit (usually 25% of price for new vehicles), instalments, and has option to purchase vehicle for Re. 1 after all instalments paid; until then, vehicle remains property of company.
Hirer gets possession but responsible for damage/loss; pays 1% interest per mensem on overdue sums; can terminate by returning vehicle.
Gujarat State sought to tax certain hire-purchase transactions where goods were within Gujarat when option to purchase exercised.
Earlier litigation: Instalment Supply Pvt. Ltd. v. Union of India, 1962 2 SCR 644, where Delhi State taxed similar transactions under Bengal Finance Sales Tax Act, 1941, upheld by Supreme Court.
In disputed transactions, hire-purchase agreement entered in Delhi, instalments paid in Delhi, option exercised in Delhi, but goods/vehicles were in Gujarat when option exercised and property passed.
Petitions filed under Article 32 challenging constitutionality of s.2(28) of Gujarat Sales Tax Act.

legal_issues.text: When does a sale liable to sales tax take place under a hire-purchase agreement?

Whether Gujarat State can levy sales tax on hire-purchase transaction where goods are within Gujarat at the time property passes upon exercise of option to purchase, even if agreement concluded in Delhi?

petitioner_arguments.text: Hire-purchase agreement does not constitute a sale until option exercised; Gujarat cannot tax as no real sale or sale deemed outside state.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Sale of Goods Act s.4; prior precedents like Johar Co.

petitioner_arguments.text: Section 2(28) of Gujarat Act unconstitutionally extends concept of sale to hire-purchase agreements.

respondent_arguments.text: Sale occurs when option exercised and property passes; under Gujarat Act s.2(28) incorporating Central Sales Tax Act s.4(2), sale inside Gujarat if goods within state at that time.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Gujarat Sales Tax Act s.2(28); Central Sales Tax Act s.4(2)

respondent_arguments.text: No petition under Art.32 lies as challenge is to assessment, not constitutionality.

court_reasoning.text: Distinguishes sale (transfer of property for price) from hire-purchase (bailment with option to purchase; no sale until option exercised).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Essence of hire-purchase is property does not pass at agreement but only on exercising option after terms fulfilled.

court_reasoning.text: Taxable event is actual sale when option exercised; if goods in Gujarat then, state can tax per s.2(28) incorporating Central Sales Tax Act s.4(2).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Agreement in Delhi, but sale completed by property passing in Gujarat.

court_reasoning.text: State legislature cannot deem hire-purchase as sale (unlike Parliament), but here actual sale occurred in Gujarat.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Unlike earlier Instalment Supply case (deemed sale), this is real sale.

court_reasoning.text: Petition maintainable under Art.32 as challenges constitutionality of s.2(28).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Per Ujjam Bai, lies where statute ultra vires.

holdings.text: Sale under hire-purchase agreement takes place only when hirer exercises option to purchase after paying instalments, and property passes.
Gujarat competent to tax such sale if goods within state when property passes, per s.2(28).

precedents_cited.case_name: Instalment Supply Pvt. Ltd. v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Upheld Delhi tax on hire-purchase as deemed sale by Parliament; distinguished as here actual sale.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mithan Lal v. State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Parliament can deem non-sales as sales for tax unlike states.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Madras v. Gannon Dunkerley & Co. (Madras) Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: States cannot tax works contracts as sales.
No sale in hire-purchase till option exercised; states cannot deem it sale.

precedents_cited.case_name: Smt. Ujjam Bai v. State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Art.32 lies if statute ultra vires or action without jurisdiction.

statutes_cited.name: Gujarat Sales Tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines sale including where goods inside state per Central Sales Tax Act s.4(2); applied to tax actual sale in state.

statutes_cited.name: Bengal Finance (Sales Tax) Act, 1941
statutes_cited.relevance: Deemed hire-purchase as sale; applied in Delhi earlier case; amended 1959.

statutes_cited.name: Sale of Goods Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines contract of sale as transfer/agreement to transfer property for price; distinguishes from hire-purchase.

statutes_cited.name: Central Sales Tax Act, 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: Sale inside state if goods within state when contract made (specific goods); incorporated in Gujarat Act.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Art.32 for petition; Art.246 limits state power vs. plenary Parliament power.

outcome.summary: Writ petitions challenging Gujarat sales tax levy on hire-purchase transactions dismissed; court held actual sale occurred in Gujarat when property passed upon option exercise, making it taxable there; no order as to costs.

key_quotes.text: "The essence of a sale is that the property is transferred from the seller to the buyer for a price, whether paid at once or paid later in instalments."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The distinguishing feature of a typical hire purchase agreement is that the property does not pass when the agreement is made but only passes when the option is finally exercised."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines when sale occurs in hire-purchase.

key_quotes.text: "The sale itself took place only when the hirer exercised his option to purchase and that was when the goods were inside the State of Gujarat."
key_quotes.speaker: court
